entry.title: BADI_EDOC_TR_INVOICE_CHANGE : how to map a header text to the Invoice/cbc:Note tag in the XML file
entry.content:
Dear All,

Requirement : in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, put the header text of a Billing Document in the XML document

I'm implementing the BADI_EDOC_TR_INVOICE_CHANGE to fulfill this requirement.

In the documentation of this BAdI Definition, there is the following paragraph :

"

To map a specific header text of source documents to the Invoice/cbc:Note tag in XML files, you can proceed as follows:

  1. Create a custom field in the Custom Fields and Logic app. Use the Sales: Billing Document business context.

You map a specific header text of source documents to this custom field.

  1. In your BAdI implementation, you map the custom field to the Invoice/cbc:Note tag in XML files.

"

I know how to create a Custom Field, but how can "You map a specific header text of source documents to this custom field." ?

The Header Text of a Billing Document is not accessible in a BAdI implementation :

  • Option 1 : CDS :  I_BillingDocumentTextTP : the field "Long Text" is not populated
  • Option 2 : EML : fails, with the error message : Statement "READ ENTITIES" is not allowed with this status
  • Option 3 : API : API_BILLING_DOCUMENT_SRV : fails with Calling "GET_HTTP_REQUEST" "violates transactional contract "FUNCTIONAL"

Many thanks for sharing your ideas.

Kind Regards

Hans

entry.title: Re: Need guidance on Bank reconciliation
entry.content:
Hi Nithin,
As requested, please find below the simplified steps for Bank Reconciliation in SAP
1. Set Up Bank Master Data
Create house banks using transaction code FI12.
Define bank accounts (main, incoming, outgoing) and link them to GL accounts.

2. Configure Electronic Bank Statement (EBS)
Set global parameters for EBS.
Create account symbols (e.g., for bank charges, check issued, check received).
Define posting rules for each account symbol.
Assign transaction types to posting rules.
Link external transaction types to posting rules.

3. Upload Bank Statement
Manual: Enter statement details manually.
Electronic: Upload MT940 or other formats via transaction FF_5 or FEBAN.

4. Automatic Matching
SAP matches bank statement items with open items in the system.
Uses predefined rules and transaction types.

5. Post and Clear Transactions
System posts entries and clears matched items.
Unmatched items are flagged for manual review.

6. Manual Reconciliation (if needed)
Use FEBA or FEBAN to manually match and clear items.
Adjust entries or post corrections if necessary.

7. Review and Finalize
Check reconciliation reports.
Ensure all discrepancies are resolved.
Post final entries to reflect accurate balances.

Hope the above steps help you.

entry.title: Re: Switch off clearing specific to ledger group
entry.content:
Dear Gab,
You are right to be cautious with this setting. In SAP ECC, once the "Clearing Specific to Ledger Group" option is activated for a GL account, especially for P&L accounts, reverting it is not straightforward and may not be directly supported through standard configuration.

The limitations of ECC
No direct reversal: Unlike SAP S/4HANA, ECC does not provide a standard method to deactivate the "Clearing Specific to Ledger Group" flag once it's been set for a GL account.

OSS Note Reference: SAP Note 1646466 confirms that ledger-specific clearing is not supported for GL accounts in ECC, especially for open item managed accounts.

We can do workaround and follow this approach.

Create a new GL account without the ledger-specific clearing flag.
Transfer balances from the old account to the new one.
Update your configuration and reporting to reflect the new account.


Suggested Steps
Create a new GL account:
Ensure it mirrors the original account‚Äôs settings except for the clearing-specific flag.
Do not enable open item management if not required.

Transfer balances:
Use manual journal entries or a clearing transaction to move balances appropriately.

Update master data:
Replace the old GL account in relevant configurations (e.g., account determination, cost elements).

Document the change:
For audit and reconciliation purposes, maintain clear documentation of the transition.

If you're planning a migration to S/4HANA soon, you might consider handling this during the conversion process where more flexibility is available.

Hope above workaround solution help you

entry.title: Re: how to generate RFQ in SAP MM Module
entry.content:
Hi Amol,
As requested please find detail process of RFQ. The RFQ is a formal invitation sent to vendors asking them to submit quotations for supplying goods or services. It helps organizations compare offers and select the best vendor based on price, delivery terms, and other conditions

RFQ Process Flow in SAP MM

1. Create RFQ (Transaction Code: ME41)
Path: Logistics ‚Üí Materials Management ‚Üí Purchasing ‚Üí RFQ/Quotation ‚Üí Request for Quotation ‚Üí Create

Details to enter:
(a) RFQ Type (e.g., AN ‚Äì standard RFQ)
(b) Language
(c) RFQ Date
(d) Quotation Deadline
(e) Purchasing Organization & Group
(f) Delivery Date
(g) Plant & Storage Location
(h) Vendor Address
(i) Material Number, Quantity, Unit of Measure

You can create RFQs:
Manually from scratch or Automatically with reference to a Purchase Requisition

2. Maintain Quotation (Transaction Code: ME47)
Vendors respond with their quotations.
You enter the received quotations into SAP using ME47.
Include vendor-specific details like price, delivery terms, and payment conditions.

3. Compare Quotations (Transaction Code: ME49)
SAP allows you to compare multiple quotations side-by-side.
Evaluation criteria include:
Price
Delivery time
Terms and conditions
Helps identify the most suitable vendor


4. Select Vendor & Create Purchase Order (Transaction Code: ME21N)
Based on comparison, select the best vendor.
Convert the accepted quotation into a Purchase Order.
The PO is then sent to the vendor for confirmation and fulfillment.

5. Follow-Up Activities
Monitor delivery and invoice processing.
Update vendor performance records for future procurement decisions.

Hope this have given you complete understanding of SAP RFQ in MM

entry.title: BAdI Implementation for Automatic Warehouse Task Selection in the Deconsolidation Work Center in EWM
entry.content:
Introduction:

Hi, everyone.  in this blog i want to explain the BAdi implementation in the automotive spare parts business, particularly in warehouses dealing with mixed pallets. These pallets often contain many small line items- sometimes 400 or more individual parts in the single case(HU).

When we handle these mixed pallets, we typically deconsolidate the smaller materials and scan them individually as we remove them from the larger pallet. The scanning is done using a keyboard scanner connected to the deconsolidation work center.

Here‚Äôs the challenge: sometimes the same material appears across multiple line items in an inbound delivery. For example, one material might appear in five or six different line items. When the warehouse operator scans the material, the system attempts to propose the multiple warehouse task for the same material.

If a material has multiple warehouse tasks in the same handling unit (HU), SAP shows a pop-up asking the user to select the correct task. While this works, it slows down productivity because warehouse operators must make repeated manual selections for each small part.

In this example, we are working with Inbound Delivery 180000463, which contains mixed materials. Within the same case, the same material appears across different line items because, in the Inbound Delivery, it was created and packed under separate line items. Please refer to the images below.

For this example, I have set up a POSC scenario. The POSC process flow is as follows: HUs are unloaded from the door to the Goods Receipt zone, then moved from the GR zone to the deconsolidation work center. At the deconsolidation work center, the materials are deconsolidated, and based on the search strategy, the system determines the final putaway bin.

To simplify this demonstration, I have already created the required warehouse tasks, and the mixed-material handling unit is now available at the deconsolidation work center.

T code-/scwm/dcons - Login to the deconsolidation workcenter

Now, here‚Äôs the issue. When I scan a material, the same material is often linked to multiple warehouse tasks, since it appears under different inbound delivery line items.

As a result, the system prompts the user to manually select the appropriate warehouse task. In this example, there are only five tasks to choose from, but in some cases, there can be as many as 20 or 30. This means the warehouse operator has to repeatedly select the each task and then proceed, after which the quantity field is populated.

This manual selection process is not efficient and it consumes a lot of time and reduces productivity.

To improve efficiency, instead of showing a pop-up, we can use a standard SAP BAdI enhancement to automatically propose the first warehouse task and populate the quantity field. This way, the system handles the task selection in the background, reducing manual effort and improving productivity.

To implement this enhancement, we first need to identify the correct BAdI that is triggered after the product is scanned. Here, the system lists the warehouse tasks only after the scanning the product, which means there must be a BAdI connected to fetching that list of warehouse tasks.

We can identify the appropriate BAdI in two ways. The first method is by using the debugger to trace the process and determine which BAdI is being called. In the following example, we will use the debugger approach to locate the correct BAdI.

The known way of finding the BAdi is, setting the breakpoint in the method GET_INSTANCE in the class CL_EXITHANDLER

In this method, when we set a breakpoint in the GET_INSTANCE method, the changing parameter EXIT_NAME will display the BAdI name. This approach helps us identify classic BAdIs.

However, to identify a kernel BAdI, we need to set a breakpoint in the statements CALL BADI and GET BADI. This allows us to trace and determine which kernel BAdI is being triggered during the process.

In the example shown below, the breakpoint was triggered when I scanned the product at the deconsolidation work center. This is the exact point where we need to check the EXIT_NAME variable in the debugger (visible on the right-hand side).

We should continue checking each instance until we find the relevant variable that points to the correct BAdI. To do this, we can execute the program using F8, which will move to the next possible BAdI.

In this case, I observed that no relevant BAdIs were found-it executed completely and then displayed the list of warehouse tasks. This indicates that there is no classic BAdI involved in this step. Therefore, we now need to look for a kernel BAdI (new BAdI) instead.

To find the kernel BAdI, here‚Äôs what I do: after scanning the source HU and the material, I activate the debugger by entering the command /h in the command field. Once debugging is switched on, I set a breakpoint at the statements CALL BADI or GET BADI.

When the system reaches these points during execution, the debugger will stop, allowing us to identify the relevant kernel BAdI that is triggered after the scan.

Now, as you can see in the screenshot above, we‚Äôve identified the correct BAdI. The code shows the statement where lo_badi is being called, and it references the method GET_WAREHOUSE_TASK. This appears to be the right place where the system fetches the warehouse tasks after scanning, so we can proceed with our analysis using this method.

Next, I‚Äôll press F5 to go inside the code. Once inside, you can see at the top that the BAdI name and the corresponding method name are displayed. This confirms that we‚Äôve found the correct BAdI.

To validate this further, we can set a breakpoint inside the BAdI implementation. By doing so, we can observe which variables and objects are being captured and what data is being processed. Using this information, we can simulate and test our enhancement logic effectively.

Alternatively, we can also locate the relevant BAdI through SPRO. To do this, go to:
SPRO ‚Üí SCM Extended Warehouse Management ‚Üí Extended Warehouse Management ‚Üí Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) for Extended Warehouse Management.

Under this section, navigate to the master data, and within that, you‚Äôll find the workcenter. There, you can see the BAdI named ‚ÄúBAdI: Determination of Warehouse Task for Deconsolidation"

So, this is another way to identify the relevant BAdI related to the deconsolidation process in EWM.

So, we can now confirm that this BAdI and its method are correct by setting a breakpoint. Once the breakpoint is set, you can observe the parameters, which are mostly related to the warehouse task. This helps validate that we‚Äôre working with the right enhancement point.

You can also confirm it by placing the breakpoint using the BAdI implementation ID. Then, execute the process again-when the debugger stops at that point, you‚Äôll know you‚Äôve reached the correct area in the code.

In the image below, it is clearly shown that when I executed the deconsolidation and scanned the product, the system triggered debugging and stopped at the breakpoint we set in the BADI implementation. This confirms 100% that this BADI method is relevant to this place.

You can also see the Locals on the right-hand side, which is very important. The table IS_HUDR contains the HU details, while IV_INPUT shows the scanned material.

Looking at the changing parameters:

IT_WHTA_OPEN lists all the open warehouse tasks. Currently, there are eight entries in this internal table.

CV_WHTA is the changing table where, based on the user‚Äôs selection, the system populates the selected quantity.

Now that we have the list of open warehouse tasks from IT_WHTA_OPEN, we can write logic to automatically populate CV_WHTA. Once auto-populated, the system can select the next two warehouse tasks automatically, so the user won‚Äôt have to select them one by one.

Please find the below sample code for the ref. 

Now that we‚Äôve implemented and activated the BAdI, we can proceed to check its behavior at runtime through debugging. Since the breakpoint has been set under the specific user ID, it will trigger during execution. From there, we can run the process and observe the flow step by step.

In the above picture, you can see that the breakpoint has been hit. The internal table IT_WHTA_OPEN contains 8 warehouse tasks. There is also a function module used to convert the scanned material number into its unconverted form. The output of this conversion is stored in LV_SCAN_MATID, which you can see on the right-hand side.

Using this unconverted material ID, we search within the internal table IT_WHTA_OPEN. During the loop through this internal table, we compare each entry‚Äôs material ID with the scanned material ID. If a match is found, we assign the corresponding TANUM ( warehouse task number) to CV_WHTA, and then exit the loop.

As a result, the system automatically proposes the relevant error task on the front-end screen.

Conclusion:

Through this BAdI, the deconsolidation screen can automatically populate the next warehouse tasks sequentially. This explanation mainly focuses on understanding the BAdI-how to identify it, how it works, and how it will be applied in the deconsolidation process rather than the core POSC process.

I would appreciate your suggestions and feedback. Please note that all testing has been performed on the IDES S/4HANA 2023 system .Thank you.

Best Regards,

Kannan Chokkanathan.

entry.title: Re: MRP Transfer Requirement Not Defaulting Source Storag...
entry.content:
Hi Mahendra,
Please find below the solution. Maintain Source Storage Location in MRP Area Configuration
SAP ECC uses MRP Areas when you plan storage locations separately (Storage Location MRP Indicator = 2). In this case, you must explicitly define the source storage location for the MRP Area.

Please find Step-by-Step Configuration as mentioned below.

1. Create or Maintain MRP Area for Sloc B

  • Transaction: OMIZ or SPRO ‚Üí Production ‚Üí MRP ‚Üí Planning ‚Üí Define MRP Areas
  • Ensure that an MRP Area exists for Sloc B (destination).
  • If not, create one and assign it to the plant and Sloc B.

2. Assign Source Storage Location to MRP Area

  • Transaction: OMIZ or SPRO ‚Üí Production ‚Üí MRP ‚Üí Planning ‚Üí Define MRP Areas
  • Select the MRP Area for Sloc B.
  • In the "Storage Location for Stock Transfers" field, enter Sloc A as the source.
  • This tells MRP where to pull stock from when planning for Sloc B.

3. Check Material Master (MRP 4 View)

  • Ensure that the MRP Area is assigned to the material. 
  • You can do this in the MRP Area-specific view of the material master (MM02). 
  • The planning type should be set appropriately (e.g., PD for MRP).

4. Run MRP for the MRP Area

  • Transaction: MD03 (for single material) or MD01 (for total planning)
  • Make sure to select the MRP Area when running MRP.

Hope above solution help you.

entry.title: Building Joule Skills for Sales Order Queries in S/4HANA Cloud - Part 4: Process Automation
entry.content:
This is Part 4 (Final) of a 4-part hands-on workshop series on building AI-powered conversational skills using SAP Joule Studio.

  • Part 1: Environment Setup
  • Part 2: Creating Actions with OData V4
  • Part 3: Developing Conversational AI Skills
  • Part 4: Process Automation Integration

Workshop GitHub Repository: https://github.com/Tenx/joule-studio-s4hana-sales-order

Overview

In this final module, you'll learn how to create an automated process and consume it in a Joule skill. This demonstrates how to integrate business processes and workflows into your conversational AI skills, enabling end-to-end automation.

Prerequisites

  • Access to an SAP BTP tenant with Joule and Joule Studio
  • Completion of Part 1: Associate Environment
  • Completion of Part 2: Create Action Projects
  • Completion of Part 3: Create Skills
  • Email has been configured for Process Automation

What You'll Learn

  • How to create an automated process in SAP Build Process Automation
  • How to publish the process to the library
  • How to use the process in a Joule skill
  • How to test the integrated solution

Estimated Time

30 minutes

Understanding Process Integration

In order for a process to be visible in Joule Studio, the process must have been published to the library - you need to remember to release, deploy, and then publish. You publish from within the Lobby.

In this tutorial, you will create a simple automated process for sending an email with sales order information. The process will send email notifications with sales order general and detailed information as the subject and body content.

Step 1: Integrate the Process into a Joule Skill

1. Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Sales Order Assistant Joule Skill project.

2. Click Create, then Joule Skill.

3. Enter name SendEmail and description Only send email with given subject, recipient, and email body if there is draft mail in previous conversations.

4. Click Create.

5. Choose Parameters, then choose Configure beside Skill Inputs.

6. Choose Add Input three times and enter the following parameters:

Name Description Required

RecipientEmail recipient addressselect
SubjectEmail subjectselect
BodyFormat email body as HTML, replace \n with <br>.select

7. Choose the + between Trigger and End.

8. Choose Run Process.

9. Choose Browse All Processes.

10. Select your SendEmail process and choose Add.

11. Choose the Inputs tab and choose the Recipient field to open the Skill Content panel.

12. Select Recipient in the Skill Content panel to map to the input parameter.

13. Similarly map the Subject and Body fields with the corresponding inputs.

14. Configure Send Message, Choose the + before End.

15. Choose Send Message.

16. Choose Open Message Editor.

17. Enter:

  • Illustrated Message as Message Type
  • Email has been sent! as Title
  • Please check the mailbox as Text
  • New Mail as illustration

18. Click Save.

Step 2: Release and Deploy the Joule Skill

1. Choose Release.

2. In the Release Project popup, choose Release.

3. Choose Show project version to change to the Released version.

4. Choose Deploy.

5. Select your environment and then choose Deploy.

Step 3: Test Joule Skill

1. Open the SAP Build Lobby

2. Choose Control Tower, then choose the Environments tile.

3. Choose your environment.

4. Choose the Joule tab.

5. Choose Launch.

6. Choose New Conversation.

7. Enter Can you show general order info about sales order 485511

8. Choose Send.

9. For more detailed information, enter I need more details and choose Send.

10. You can check if the process has been called by going to Monitoring > Process and Workflow Instances.

Troubleshooting

If you encounter issues during process integration:

  • Process Not Visible: Ensure the process has been published to the library after release and deployment
  • Email Configuration: Verify that email has been properly configured for Process Automation
  • Skill Integration: Check that all input parameters are correctly mapped between the skill and process
  • Deployment Issues: Ensure you have the necessary permissions to deploy to your environment
  • Testing Failures: Verify that the test sales order number (485511) exists and is accessible

Congratulations!

You have completed all modules of the Building Joule Skills for Sales Order Queries in S/4HANA Cloud!

You are now equipped to build sophisticated AI-powered conversational solutions that integrate with SAP and non-SAP systems. Throughout this workshop, you've learned:

  • How to set up and configure SAP BTP for Joule Studio development
  • How to create and manage development environments
  • How to build action projects from OData V4 APIs
  • How to develop conversational AI skills with rich UI components
  • How to integrate business process automation with conversational interfaces
  • How to deploy and test end-to-end solutions

Next Steps

Now that you've completed the workshop, consider:

  • Apply to Your Business: Identify use cases in your organization where conversational AI can add value
  • Explore Advanced Features: Dive deeper into Joule Studio's advanced capabilities
  • Build Custom Solutions: Create your own skills connecting to your specific SAP and non-SAP systems
  • Share Your Knowledge: Help others in your organization adopt Joule Studio

Additional Resources

  • SAP Joule Documentation
  • Sales Order (A2X) OData V4 API Reference
  • SAP Build Process Automation Documentation
  • Workshop GitHub Repository

Part 4 of 4 (Final) | Joule Studio Workshop Series

Full Workshop: GitHub Repository

Thank you for participating in this workshop!

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud Report Formatting (Financial Stateme...
entry.content:
Hello @adnanmaqbool 

Thank you for your question. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition, the Balance Sheet/Income Statement app (F0708) produces a default PDF preview. SAP does not support replacing this with a custom Adobe form like FIGL_BSAIS_EN, and the app does not utilise Output Parameter Determination (OPD) for its PDF output. This is a known product limitation. SAP Support Portal-3380571 - 'Balance Sheet/Income Statement' PDF template - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

What actions are currently available?Use the app‚Äôs Export to PDF/Excel feature. Note that some columns might not be visible in the PDF by design, as documented.  SAP Support Portal-2951269 - PDF output from app Balance Sheet/Income Statement (F0708) does not include all columns

If you need a branded or redesigned financial statement, build it in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) or another reporting layer fed by the same S/4 data, and export that to PDF. (F0708 itself can‚Äôt switch to a custom template.) SAP Help Portal-Balance Sheet / Income Statement

For your information, references.

  • KBA 3380571 ‚Äî It is not possible to change the PDF template in app ‚ÄòBalance Sheet/Income Statement‚Äô (F0708). The document confirms that the PDF preview uses a fixed format in Public Cloud. SAP Support Portal
  • KBA 2951269 ‚Äî Explains why some columns don‚Äôt appear in the F0708 PDF export. SAP Support Portal
  • Help: Balance Sheet/Income Statement ‚Äî Functional scope of F0708 (export options, reporting). SAP Help Portal

Let me know if it helps

With regards

entry.title: Fi-AA: accumulated depreciation balance sheet account not cleared
entry.content:
Dear SAP Experts,

I have a problem/question related to SAP FI-AA (S4HANA 2508). I am posting an asset aquisition of 1.000,00 EUR on 01/09/2025 to GL account 240000000. Afterwards I am doing a depreciation run on 30/09/2025 where 20,00 EUR is posted to my balance sheet account for accumulated depreciations 240000080. This depreciation run is posted in GL.

I am doing now a scrapping without revenue on 15/10/2025. I would expect that my balance of both balance sheet account gets cleared:

- Credit asset account 240000000: 1.000 EUR

- Debit asset account accumulated depreciation 240000080: 20,00 EUR

-Debit loss account: 980,00 EUR

Unfortunatelly it does not clear my accumulated depreciation account. My posting is:

- Credit asset account 240000000: 1.000 EUR

- Debit loss account: 1.000,00 EUR

Why does it not take the old historically posted depreciation into consideration?

br,Stef

entry.title: SAP Asset Performance Management - Transport Management : Import Transport Requests to Target Tenant
entry.content:
This blog outlines one of the promising features of SAP Asset Performance Management (APM) : Transport Management process. 

The transport management functionality in SAP Asset Performance Management (APM) provides organizations with seamless navigation to SAP Cloud Management Service where organizations can view and manage transport requests and details. Organizations can manage the SAP APM Transport content using SAP CTMS (Cloud Transport Management Service) to enable the management of software deliverables across different environments, such as development, test, and production. It allows for the transport of application artifacts and content between these environments and also provides an audit trail of changes and ensuring transparency and accountability.

SAP APM - Transport Management Application

In this blog we will transport "Alphanumeric Risk & Criticality Template"  to SAP APM EIOT tenant from a source tenant.

Prerequisites:

  • One must have the role collection to access SAP CTMS. For more information, please check the link below. Role Collection 
  • Destination must have been configured for SAP CTMS in the source tenant`s subaccount. For more information, please check the link below. Configuring Destinations 
  • Transport Routes and Nodes must have been configured in the SAP CTMS. For more information, please check the link below. Transport Nodes 
  • Before transporting the templates from the source tenant, ensure that the associated objects are present in the target tenant(synchronized from S4 HANA)

Disclaimer: This blog does not showcase "Alert Notification Service" used to issue notifications for specific events - Such as when an import is started and when it`s finished.

If you want to gain a deeper understanding of SAP Asset Performance Management functions, you may access the links below.

  • SAP Asset Performance Management - Ingesting Time Series Data - Derivation & Monitor Rule Management 
  • SAP Asset Performance Management - Visual Asset Health Monitoring (Part-1) 
  • SAP Asset Performance Management - Manage Embedded IoT Metadata Sync 
  • What`s New in SAP Asset Performance Management - Release 2502 
  • Achieving Sustainability With SAP Asset Performance Management By Leveraging Industrial Systems. 
  • Configuring Failure Curve Analytics (FCA) In SAP Asset Performance Management (APM) 

Let us navigate to application " Manage Templates for Risk & Criticality Assessments" in source tenant.

Before we transport, let us first view the content of the "2025_AC_HZ_NL_Alphanumeric" template.

Alphanumeric method is used to determine overall risk and criticality values , i.e.,  Minimum or Maximum. 

For Instance I have chosen one Impact Category, i.e., Operation, and two dimensions with a 5-Point rating scale. 

Mini Note: There can be only two dimensions for Alphanumeric Template, and these are common across all impacts. We can not add new dimensions.

Dimension-1 : Consequence of the failure.

Dimension-2: Likelihood of failure.

Threshold Values.

Now let us transport this template to SAP APM EIOT using the option" Transport".

Select the target tenant from the drop down values and provide a valid description for the transport request.

The transport details can be viewed by clicking on "Go to Details" or by navigating to the Application "Job Manager". If we click on "Go to Details", the system redirects us to the Job Manager Application.

Now let us navigate to the application "Transport Management" and Import the transport request ID 209 to SAP APM EIOT tenant.

Action log of the transport request ID 209.

Before we transport the request ID 209, let us quickly check the SAP APM EIOT tenant for the count of of "Risk and Criticality Templates".

now let us import the transport request ID 209  using the option "Import Selected". The status of the Transport Request is "Initial".

Once the system imports the transport request successfully, the status of the Transport Request changes to "Succeeded".

Let us check the SAP APM EIOT tenant.

 

üòäThis brings me to the end of the walk through process on SAP Asset Performance Management (APM) - Transport Management. I hope this blog proves useful to the Plant Maintenance team. I look forward to seeing the Plant Maintenance Team leverage this promising feature during SAP APM implementation.

--

Yours Sincerely,

Pardhasaradhi Reddy. Chelikam

My LinkedIn Profile: www.linkedin.com/in/pardhreddyc

entry.title: Why the callback procedure is not called in aRFC/pRFC with Wait?
entry.content:
I've got a simple program to run tasks in parallel, which waits the end of all tasks. That's achieved by using CALL FUNCTION '<RFC-enabled function module>' STARTING NEW TASK ... PERFORMING/CALLING ... ON END OF TASK ...

The tasks are called (can be seen by forcing a short dump in the function module) but the callback subroutine is not called.

What is the problem?

Thanks.

Sandra

It happens with ABAP 7.58 but also with other ABAP versions.

The program is this one:

START-OF-SELECTION.
  DATA task_name TYPE c LENGTH 32.
  DATA rfc_error TYPE c LENGTH 255.
  TYPES:
    BEGIN OF ty_result,
      input_number           TYPE i,
      square_of_input_number TYPE i,
    END OF ty_result.
  DATA results TYPE TABLE OF ty_result.
  DO 3 TIMES.
    CALL FUNCTION 'Z_RFC_SQUARE'
         STARTING NEW TASK task_name
         PERFORMING on_end_of_task ON END OF TASK
      EXPORTING  input_number          = sy-index
      EXCEPTIONS communication_failure = 1 MESSAGE rfc_error
                 system_failure        = 2 MESSAGE rfc_error
                 OTHERS                = 3.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      ASSERT 1 = 1. " dummy statement for setting a breakpoint (if debug needed)
    ENDIF.
  ENDDO.
  WAIT UNTIL 0 = 1.
  LOOP AT results INTO DATA(result).
    WRITE : / result-input_number, result-square_of_input_number.
  ENDLOOP.
  ASSERT 1 = 1. " dummy statement for setting a breakpoint (if debug needed)

FORM on_end_of_task USING p_task TYPE c.
  DATA result TYPE ty_result.
  RECEIVE RESULTS FROM FUNCTION 'Z_RFC_SQUARE'
    IMPORTING input_number           = result-input_number
              square_of_input_number = result-square_of_input_number.
  INSERT result INTO TABLE results.
ENDFORM.

The function module Z_RFC_SQUARE is this one, and it's defined as RFC-enabled:

FUNCTION z_rfc_square
  IMPORTING VALUE(input_number)           TYPE i
  EXPORTING VALUE(input_number)           TYPE i
            VALUE(square_of_input_number) TYPE i.
  square_of_input_number = input_number * input_number.
ENDFUNCTION.

entry.title: Re: Why the callback procedure is not called in aRFC/pRFC with Wait?
entry.content:
The issue is due to TASK_NAME being empty.

If a callback procedure is defined with aRFC or pRFC (PERFORMING/CALLING), the task name TASK_NAME:

  • must be initialized with a non-empty name
  • must be unique. If not unique, the exception COMMUNICATION_FAILURE may happen if one task is running with the same task, and this error message is returned: "RFC task <task name> already open."
  • NB: if TASK_NAME is empty, the callback procedure is not called when the task is ended. Note that the ABAP documentation doesn't describe this behavior.

Here is the working code, the only change is to initialize TASK_NAME with a non-empty and unique value (NB: the function module is unchanged):

 

START-OF-SELECTION.
  DATA task_name TYPE c LENGTH 32.
  DATA rfc_error TYPE c LENGTH 255.
  TYPES:
    BEGIN OF ty_result,
      input_number           TYPE i,
      square_of_input_number TYPE i,
    END OF ty_result.
  DATA results TYPE TABLE OF ty_result.
  DO 3 TIMES.
    task_name = |A{ sy-index }|.
    CALL FUNCTION 'Z_RFC_SQUARE'
         STARTING NEW TASK task_name
         PERFORMING on_end_of_task ON END OF TASK
      EXPORTING  input_number          = sy-index
      EXCEPTIONS communication_failure = 1 MESSAGE rfc_error
                 system_failure        = 2 MESSAGE rfc_error
                 OTHERS                = 3.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      ASSERT 1 = 1. " dummy statement for setting a breakpoint (if debug needed)
    ENDIF.
  ENDDO.
  WAIT UNTIL 0 = 1.
  LOOP AT results INTO DATA(result).
    WRITE : / result-input_number, result-square_of_input_number.
  ENDLOOP.
  ASSERT 1 = 1. " dummy statement for setting a breakpoint (if debug needed)

FORM on_end_of_task USING p_task TYPE c.
  DATA result TYPE ty_result.
  RECEIVE RESULTS FROM FUNCTION 'Z_RFC_SQUARE'
    IMPORTING input_number           = result-input_number
              square_of_input_number = result-square_of_input_number.
  INSERT result INTO TABLE results.
ENDFORM.

Result:

12.10.2025           Square calculation in parallel           1
---------------------------------------------------------------
         1           1 
         2           4 
         3           9

entry.title: SAP Datasphere Connector for REST API
entry.content:
Hello experts, 

I want to connect a third-party REST API (Eurostat) to SAP Datasphere. This should be a simple GET REST request where data is read and should be saved into a local table in Datasphere. 

The GET request in Postman is working. 
Example URI: https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/api/dissemination/statistics/1.0/data/nama_10_gdp?format=JSON&time=2025 

However, in SAP Datasphere I only find the generic Odata connector. This is not working in the validation, error: 406 not accepted. Probably this is due to the fact, that it is a REST-API and no Odata endpoint... 
Cause: Invalid odata connection! Getting odata metadata failed because of (406) Not Acceptable [HTTP/1.1 406 Not Acceptable]

We tested the generic HTTP connector too. This was validated and saved successfully. The problem here is that in the API task (in the task chain) only supports POST and PUT operations, no GET operation. So, this is as well no option. 

As we researched for Datasphere and REST-APIs we found this blog article. 
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/streamlining-rest-api-integrations-in-sap-datasphere-with-task-chains-and/ba-p/14169273 
Is this the only option to connect REST APIs with an additionally BTP microservice? Is there no option in the SAP standard of Datasphere?

Thanks for your help!

Best regards,
Sarah

entry.title: Preparing for SuccessFactors Associate Certification Exam with Google NotebookLM in the Age of AI
entry.content:
Introduction

As a SuccessFactors consultant holding certifications across nine modules, I deeply understand that preparing for certification has traditionally been a manual, time-intensive process involving extensive note-taking, highlighting, and manual flashcard creation. However, the advent of AI-powered tools like Google NotebookLM is fundamentally transforming this workflow.

This article introduces an intelligent, AI-driven approach to certification preparation, contrasting it with traditional methods to demonstrate how consultants can significantly enhance learning efficiency and content internalization. By automating repetitive tasks, AI allows a greater focus on comprehension, practical application, and performance improvement, making the path to certification smarter and faster. I hope that sharing this transition will inspire fellow learners and help accelerate your own certification preparation journey.

Previous Learning Workflow

To illustrate the contrast, let‚Äôs look at my earlier preparation process when I was pursuing my first SAP certification for Recruiting Management (RCM). The standard approach begins with the official SAP Learning Journey, followed by a meticulous, manual review about the moudle. Key activities typically include:

  • Following the prescribed SAP Learning Journeys path to know the learning path and build a foundational understanding.
  • Manually copying the content, highlighting key points and then structuring notes in applications like Notion.
  • Using tools like MarginNote3 to create visual mind maps from implementation guides for conceptual clarity.
  • Practicing with sample questions and peer-shared materials to identify knowledge gaps.
  • Revisiting weak areas based on the topic weight distribution outlined in the official exam guide. Note: Based on my exam experience, most certification questions originate from the official Learning Journey content rather than implementation guides. Therefore, if your goal is to pass the certification efficiently, prioritizing the Learning Journey materials is recommended over full implementation documents.

My Notion Note

My MarginNote3 Demo

How AI Empowers My Learning Process Now

ItemsBeforeNow with AI Note
Note TakingManually restructured official materialsSimply paste the SAP Learning Site URL to automatically parse and summarize contentSAP no longer provides downloadable PDFs as of 2025 directly, so copying URLs or content into Google NotebookLM is essential.
Mind MapUsed third-party tools and manually created diagramsAI automatically generates structured mind maps from collected materialsYou can directly ask contextual questions about each note.
Question Test GenerationCreated flashcards in MarginNote or Anki manuallyAI automatically generates quizzes based on topic weights or personal weaknessesRefer to ‚ÄúTopics covered in this exam‚Äù for section weights.
FlashcardAdded flashcards manually based on memory or shared contentAI generates flashcards dynamically aligned with your weak topicsEnsures focus on high-weight exam areas.
Question CheckRelied on keyword searches or senior consultant confirmationAI provides responses with citations from official sourcesAsk AI to validate questions and cite authoritative sources.

Sample Prompts

Below are example AI prompts to assist your learning and preparation workflow.

Items
Sample AI Prompt
 Note
Question Test GenerationRole: You are an expert exam creator specializing in SAP technologies.

Task: Generate a 20-question multiple-choice quiz to help me prepare for the SAP Generative AI Developer certification exam.

Strict Instructions:
1. Source Constraint:
‚Ä¢ Base all questions and answers strictly and exclusively on the information contained in my uploaded ‚Äòwebsite‚Äô sources.
‚Ä¢ Do not use any outside knowledge.

2. Question Distribution (20 Total Questions):
‚Ä¢ SAP AI Core: 3 questions
‚Ä¢ SAP‚Äôs Generative AI Hub: 7 questions
‚Ä¢ Large Language Models (LLMs): 5 questions
‚Ä¢ Advanced AI Techniques with SAP‚Äôs Generative AI Hub: 5 questions

3. Content Exclusion:
‚Ä¢ Explicitly exclude any questions related to data privacy strategy.

4. Output Format:
‚Ä¢ Present all 20 questions, numbered 1 through 20.
‚Ä¢ Each question should include four options labeled A, B, C, and D.
‚Ä¢ Include a separate ‚ÄúAnswer Key‚Äù section listing correct answers for all questions.		You may customize the difficulty level and number of questions as needed.
Please avoid referencing implementation guide PDFs.
You can also add further restrictions or exclusions as necessary.
FlashcardRole: You are an expert instructional designer creating a flashcard study set for the SAP Generative AI Developer certification exam.

Task: Generate a set of exactly 100 digital flashcards.

Core Directives:
1. Source Constraint:
‚Ä¢ Use only uploaded ‚Äòwebsite‚Äô sources.
‚Ä¢ Do not use PDF materials or external references.

2. Flashcard Content & Style:
‚Ä¢ Front: A single key term, acronym, concept, or direct question (e.g., ‚ÄúWhat is the primary function of the SAP Generative AI Hub?‚Äù).
‚Ä¢ Back: A concise and direct definition or explanation (use bullet points where needed).
‚Ä¢ Each card should focus on a single examinable concept.

3. Topic Distribution (100 Total Flashcards):
‚Ä¢ SAP AI Core: 15 flashcards
‚Ä¢ SAP‚Äôs Generative AI Hub: 35 flashcards
‚Ä¢ Large Language Models (LLMs): 25 flashcards
‚Ä¢ Advanced AI Techniques with SAP‚Äôs Generative AI Hub: 25 flashcards

4. Content Exclusion:
‚Ä¢ Exclude any flashcards related to data privacy strategy.

5. Output Format:
‚Ä¢ Number flashcards from 1 to 100.
‚Ä¢ Label each with ‚ÄúFront:‚Äù and ‚ÄúBack:‚Äù.

Example Format:
1.
Front: SAP AI Core
Back: A service on SAP BTP that enables the development, deployment, and management of AI and machine learning models.		You may adjust the difficulty level and number of cards as needed.
Do not reference implementation guide PDFs when creating flashcards.
Additional constraints or exclusions can be added to fit learning needs.
Question CheckTask: Analyze the following multiple-choice question using only my uploaded sources.

Question:
What are some drivers for the rapid adoption of generative AI?

Answer Options:
‚Ä¢ Availability of skilled developers
‚Ä¢ Significant hardware cost savings
‚Ä¢ Wide availability
‚Ä¢ Ease of use
(Note: There are 2 correct answers)

Your Task:
1. Identify the two correct answers from the list.
2. Provide direct supporting quotes from my uploaded sources.
3. Cite each source explicitly to justify the selected answers.		Recommended to use "Learning Guide" as conversational style.
You may modify tone or response length depending on desired learning depth.

Google Notebook Material Source

1. Materials from SAP Learning Hub
You can directly reference SAP Learning Hub content in Google NotebookLM by copying individual lesson URLs. Unfortunately, the platform does not currently support accessing all materials through a single consolidated link. Example links include:

  • Describing LLMs
  • Starting from Ideation to Productization
    Limitation: Visual assets such as images and embedded videos from the Learning Journey site cannot be captured by Google NotebookLM.

2. Certificate Section Weight in Exam
For precise exam preparation, copy the ‚ÄúTopics covered in this exam‚Äù section from the SAP Certification page. This helps you identify the weight assigned to each exam topic, which can be used as structured input for AI prompts.
URL: SAP Certifications

3. Help Guides from SAP Help Portal
Download implementation PDFs from the SAP Help Portal as supplementary materials for Q&A and deeper exploration. These guides are especially useful for validating configuration question.
URL: SAP Help Portal

4. Question Library
In addition to official sample questions available on the SAP website, collect frequently asked or memorized questions shared by experienced consultants. These community-sourced insights can be valuable references when used responsibly to identify weak areas and simulate realistic exam conditions.

Note: You could use AI to restructure and format the questions library.

Example Outputs

Mind Map Demo

Flashcard Demo


Quiz Demo

Question Chat Demo

Conclusion

AI tools such as Google NotebookLM have fundamentally reshaped how SAP consultants can prepare for certification exams. By automating repetitive tasks like note-taking, flashcard creation, and question generation, consultants can allocate more time to mastering key concepts and refining their practical understanding. The integration of AI into the SAP learning journey not only boosts efficiency but also enhances comprehension‚Äîmaking certification preparation smarter, faster, and more enjoyable. You can access the sample Google Notebook I created for SAP Generative AI study and certification preparation using the link below:
üîóSAP Generative AI Notebook (Google NotebookLM)

entry.title: 2H 2025 - Release highlights of SuccessFactors Career Development Planning
entry.content:
Hi Community,

The 2H 2025 release is here!

A new set of enhancements has been released in the 2H 2025 release that has been eagerly awaited. The SAP SuccessFactors 2H 2025 Release includes some key features and enhancements, so let's take a closer look!

1- AI-Assisted Career Insights for Current Role:

Leveraging generative AI capabilities, employees can gain insights into development actions that help them progress in their current role. Previously, the feature was only available for target roles.

In the latest Career Worksheet, employees can access the feature by choosing the Generate button in the new Unlock your potential with AI-powered insights! section on a current role's details page. Generative AI produces insights by considering employees' current role and Growth Portfolio information, including the following:

  • Role name and description
  • Skills and attributes associated with the role
  • Current and expected proficiency levels for these skills and attributes
  • Skills and attributes added to the employee's Growth Portfolio

The insights are organized into sections to help employees grasp the most important aspects of their development:

  • Summary: Provides a high-level overview of the employee's current role.
  • Suggestions for Improvement: Identifies two growth areas for upskilling and career development, and for each area, provides achievable suggestions in the following aspects:
    • Skills and attributes in this category
    • Keywords of learning courses
    • Ideal mentor's position
    • Suggested development goal. Employees can use the link provided to directly create a development goal from scratch or with the help of generative AI.
  • Career Directions for You: Outlines tailored career roles and provides a link to explore recommended job roles in the organization.

Enablement: Contact Customer Engagement Executive or Account Manager

Configuration Requirements:

  • You've enabled the latest Career Worksheet.
  • You've purchased the AI units license. For more information about AI units license, please contact your Account Executive.
  • You've enabled the AI Services Administration>Assisted Career Insights option.
  • You've consented to the AI Usage Acknowledgment Statement.

Role-Based Permission Prerequisites:

  • Administrators have the Administrator Permissions>Manage AI Capabilities>AI Services Administration permission.
  • Employees have the User Permissions>AI Access>Assisted Career Insights permission.

2- AI-Assisted Writing Available in Custom Learning Activities:

AI-assisted writing is now available in the text and textarea fields of custom learning activities.

Enablement: Contact Customer Engagement Executive or Account Manager

Configuration Requirements:

  • You've purchased the AI units license. For more information about AI units license, please contact your Account Executive.
  • You've enabled the AI Services Administration>Assisted Writing option in Admin Center.
  • For Translation: You‚Äôve also enabled the AI Services Administration>Assisted Writing  Translation option in Admin Center.

Role-Based Permission Prerequisites:

  • Administrators have the Administrator>Manage AI Capabilities>AI Services Administration permission.
  • Employees have the User Permissions>AI Access>Assisted Writing permission.

3- Create Development Goals with AI Based on Roles and Interests:

Users can now use generative AI to create development goals based on a current role, target role, or skills and attributes.

Enablement: Contact Customer Engagement Executive or Account Manager

Configuration Requirements:

  • You've purchased the AI units license. For more information about AI units license, please contact your Account Executive.
  • You've enabled the AI Services Administration>Assisted Development Goals option.
  • You've consented to the AI Usage Acknowledgment Statement.
  • In addition to the above, be aware of the prerequisites for the availability of each goal creation option.

Role-Based Permission Prerequisites:

  • Administrators have the Administrator>Manage AI Capabilities>AI Services Administration permission.
  • Users have the User>AI Access>Assisted Development Goals permission.

4- Data Referenced Section Available in AI-Assisted Career Insights:

When employees use generative AI capabilities to generate career insights, they can view what information is being considered in the Data Referenced section on a target role's details page in the latest Career Worksheet.

Enablement: Automatically On

Configuration Requirements:

  • You've enabled the AI-assisted career insights feature by enabling the AI Services Administration>Assisted Career Insights option.

Role-Based Permission Prerequisites:

  • Users have the User>AI Access>Assisted Career Insights permission.

5- Exclude Job Codes from Data Sync for Career Explorer:

You can now exclude job codes from data sync between your system and the People Connection system, so that associated job roles won't be recommended to employees in Career Explorer.

To do this, go to the Manage People Connection Integration admin tool and select Manage Job Codes for Data Sync. You also have an option to exclude all inactive job codes from data sync. When you configure the integration with People Connection for the first time, the selected job codes are excluded from data sync immediately; otherwise, the selected job codes are excluded during the next data training session. Here's a screenshot of the feature.

Enablement: Automatically On

Role-Based Permission Prerequisites:

  • You have the Administrator>People Connection>Manage People Connection Integration permission.

6- Option to Disable Legacy Career Worksheet:

If you've enabled the latest Career Worksheet, you can now choose to disable the legacy version.

The Disable the Legacy Career Worksheet setting is available in the Career Development Planning Feature Settings admin tool. When the legacy version is disabled, the Career Worksheet tab isn't available in the Development module. If you don't use the Career Path, Mentoring, or Career Explorer feature, the Development module is no longer available in the main navigation menu.

If you haven't enabled the latest Career Worksheet, the Career Development Planning Feature Settings admin tool isn't available in your system.

Configuration Requirements:

  • You've enabled the latest Career Worksheet.

Role-Based Permission Prerequisites:

  • Administrator>Manage Career Development>Career Development Planning Feature Settings permission

7- View Development Goals in Latest Career Worksheet:

Users can now view their development goals on a role's details page in the latest Career Worksheet.

Enablement: Customer Configured

Configuration Requirements:

  • You've enabled the latest Career Worksheet.
  • Users have the access permission to the default development goal plan template.
  • Users have at least the view permission for the name field in the default development goal plan template.
  • The competencies field is configured in the default development goal plan template and users have at least the view permission for the field.

8- View Recommended Assignments and Learning Opportunities for Development Goals:

Users can now view assignments and learning opportunities that match skills and attributes selected for their development goals. They can also choose to link assignments of interest to their development goals.

The feature is only available on users' own goal details page. If users have selected skills or attributes for a development goal that match those required by assignments or learning, the assignments and learning are recommended in the Opportunities to Grow section on the goal details page. A Go to Opportunity Marketplace link is available for them to explore more opportunities in Opportunity Marketplace.

Enablement: Customer Configured

For a detailed release summary, check out the ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs New Viewer‚Äù for a list of enhancements across the application.

 

Configuration Requirements:

  • You've enabled the latest Goal Management.
  • The competencies field is configured in the development goal plan template.
  • Users have read or write permission to the competencies field.
  • You've enabled assignments and learning opportunities in Opportunity Marketplace.

Role-Based Permission Prerequisites:

  • User>Opportunity Marketplace>Opportunity Marketplace Access
  • User>Opportunity Marketplace>View Assignments
  • User>Learning>Learning Access Permission

entry.title: New Candidate Type Default Option on Candidate Search After 2H 2025 in SuccessFactors Recruiting
entry.content:
After the 2H 2025, the Candidate Type option in the Candidate Search is now defaulting to "External" when the page is opened. 

This change has been introduced to improve the systems performance when searching Candidates in the Candidate Search page.

After 2H 2025, if Users are looking for both External and Internal Candidates, they'll need to manually change the option.

3666843 - New Candidate Type Default Option After 2H 2025 Release - Recruiting Management

entry.title: Re: Free Form Payment Request ‚Äì Release Dual Control
entry.content:
Hello @slucic,

Yes. For SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, you can use SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) with SAP‚Äôs pre-built Free Form Payment Approval.

It operates on SAP BTP, connects to your Cloud tenant, and works with the Process/My Free Form Payments (F2564) applications. The guide and package are edition-agnostic (BPT-side) Cloud. My Free Form Payments

A few key points to note:

  • The SBPA workflow adds approval steps before/around release; it does not remove the built-in dual control in Public Cloud. The creator and releaser still must be different users, that is, message FIBL_RPCODE141.SAP Support Portal-3493984 - Error when releasing a Free Form Payment
  • Subscribe to SAP Build Process Automation, import Free Form Payment Approval from Business Accelerator Hub, configure S/4HANA Cloud connections, set approver rules, and deploy. The Setup PDF guides these steps. SAP Build Process Automation Integration with SAP S/4HANA for Free Form Payments Approval

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: The amount of activity type is not correct and how to...
entry.content:
Hello @garyding 

Your proposed setup, Assessment from CC 100_CE ‚Üí WBS1‚ÄìWBS4, with split proportional to actuals on 50301000 and posting on secondary CE 92105400, looks correct for Public Cloud.

If Finance requires 50307000 on the P&L per WBS, maintain the allocation on the secondary CE for audit purposes, and create a separate FI reclass/reporting map.

Universal Allocation is the right tool. It supports allocating actuals from a sender cost center to WBS elements and lets you weight the split by receiver tracing factors. SAP Help Portal-Sales Accounting-Universal Allocation

WBS elements serve as valid receivers. According to SAP Help, WBS are listed alongside cost centers, profit centers, and other standard receivers. SAP Help Portal-Divisional Accounting-Receivers

Assessment posts on a secondary cost element (your 92105400 idea). Allocations between cost objects are recorded using secondary cost elements, which is the standard pattern in S/4HANA. SAP Help Portal-Overhead Accounting-Cost Element Categories

The driver, based on actual cost element values, aligns with the receiver tracing factors concept in Manage Allocations, where variable portions are determined by actual values rather than fixed percentages or portions. SAP Help Portal-Divisional Accounting-Manage Allocations (New Version)

A costing sheet is not a replacement. It calculates overhead on the receiver‚Äôs base percent/quantity rates. for orders/projects, not for drawing from a fixed sender cost center pool. SAP Help Portal-Overhead Accounting-Costing Sheet

Let me know if it works

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Legal entities operating in multiple countries/regions
entry.content:
Hello @ngel_Pobo33 

RITA is SAP's standard system for managing indirect tax across various countries within a single legal entity, such as one company code. This aligns with SAP Help's description of RITA's capabilities. SAP Help Portal--General Ledger Accounting-Registration for Indirect Taxation Abroad (RITA)

The SAP documents explain where RITA is enabled and how you can activate or maintain tax registration in the configuration. This confirms that it‚Äôs the supported model, rather than just a temporary workaround. SAP Help Portal-Countries/Regions Where RITA is Enabled

Options without RITA are restricted and depend on the situation.

Plants Abroad can manage certain cross-border cases, but it‚Äôs not a complete replacement for multi-country registration and reporting. Activating Plants Abroad in SAP

External tax engines like Vertex or Avalara can enhance calculation accuracy, but a compliant method for modelling registrations and reporting, usually RITA combined with SAP DRC, is still necessary. SAP Vertex -Automate global indirect tax determination and compliance with SAP S/4HANA

Your original answer is correct, use RITA for a single legal entity operating across multiple tax jurisdictions. If RITA‚Äôs scope raises concerns, review the list of enabled countries and release documentation, or think about splitting by company code fallback. SAP Help Portal-Countries/Regions Where RITA is Enabled

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Need guidance on Bank reconciliation
entry.content:
Hi @nithin_pranesh 

Thank you for the question.

The question is somewhat generic. Depending on the issue you are trying to resolve, specific answers can be provided.

Considering the topic is quite broad, I suggest you get a clear overview of your needs by reading through the documentations. Otherwise you can provide a specific issue you are trying to resolve and we will be happy to help.

Below is a summary of steps you may consider:

  1. Upload the Bank Statement either electronically or manually
  2. Automatic Matching of transaction with SAP open items
  3. Manual Reprocessing of unmatched entries
  4. Post the Bank Statement to update GL
  5. Verify reconciliation
  6. Resolve any differences that comes up if any.

The following references provide further details.

Reconciliation

Reprocess Bank Statement Items

Bank Account Balance Reconciliation

SAP KBA 3374309

Regarding common tips,

  • It is important that you use electronic bank statement if you are carrying out any automation.
  • Make sure you maintain clear posting rules and reconcile regularly to avoid mismatches.
  • Avoid waiting till month end becuase small mismatches may accumulate.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Refresh Object Page after Action Execution with Custo...
entry.content:
Hello @liutiuriu 

You can refresh the Object Page using RAP (ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model) by exposing your Custom Entity through a behaviour projection and enabling side effects.

In the base behavior, declare side effects {action <YourAction> affects $self, messages, permissions; }

In projection behavior, add use side effects and expose the projection in your service.
Fiori elements (OData V4) will remind the page after the action. See RAP side effects and projection behavior docs. SAP Help Portal-ABAP Keywood Documentation-RAP - side effects

With kind regards

Chuma

ÂÖÉ„ÅÆ„Éá„Éº„Çø„Å´„ÅØÂ§öÊï∞„ÅÆËø∞Ë™ûÔºàpredicateÔºâ„ÅåÂê´„Åæ„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÄÅ„Åì„Åì„Åß„ÅØ rowID„ÄÅdscrptÔºàË™¨ÊòéÊñáÔºâ„ÄÅinfl_outflÔºàÂÖ•Âá∫ÈáëÔºâ „Å®„ÅÑ„Å£„ÅüÁâπÂÆö„ÅÆËø∞Ë™û„ÇíÊåÅ„Å§„Éà„É™„Éó„É´„ÅÆ„Åø„Çí„ÄÅÂêçÂâçÁ©∫Èñì„ÇíÊåáÂÆö„Åó„Å¶ÊäΩÂá∫„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇÂêçÂâçÁ©∫ÈñìÔºànamespaceÔºâ „Å®„ÅØ„ÄÅÂêÑË¶ÅÁ¥†„Å´‰∏ÄÊÑè„ÅÆË≠òÂà•Â≠ê„Çí‰ªò‰∏é„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆÁØÑÂõ≤„ÇíÊåá„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇÊú¨ÊâãÈ†Ü„Åß„ÅØ„ÄÅ„Ç≥„Éº„Éâ„ÅÆÂèØË™≠ÊÄß„ÇíÈ´ò„ÇÅ„ÇãÁõÆÁöÑ„ÅßÂÆöÁæ©„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

„Åù„ÅÆÂæå„ÄÅ„Éï„Ç£„É´„Çø„É™„É≥„Ç∞„Åó„Åü„Éá„Éº„Çø„Çí Turtle ÂΩ¢Âºè „Åß‰øùÂ≠ò„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇTurtle „ÅØ RDF „Éá„Éº„Çø„ÇíË°®Áèæ„Åô„Çã„Éï„Ç©„Éº„Éû„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆ‰∏Ä„Å§„Åß„ÅÇ„Çä„ÄÅÂèØË™≠ÊÄß„ÅåÈ´ò„Åè„ÄÅSPARQL „ÇØ„Ç®„É™„Å®„ÅÆË¶™ÂíåÊÄß„Å´„ÇÇÂÑ™„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

# „Éï„Ç£„É´„Çø„É™„É≥„Ç∞Áî®„ÅÆ„Ç∞„É©„Éï‰ΩúÊàê
filtered = Graph()

# ÂêçÂâçÁ©∫Èñì„ÅÆÂÆöÁæ©
ns1 = Namespace("http://www.socrata.com/rdf/terms#")
ns2 = Namespace("https://data.cityofnewyork.us/resource/_4ubz-8kkx/")

filtered.bind("ns1", ns1)
filtered.bind("ns2", ns2)

# ÊåáÂÆö„Åï„Çå„Åü„Éó„É≠„Éë„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÅÆ„Åø„Çí„Éï„Ç£„É´„Çø„É™„É≥„Ç∞
for s, p, o in g:
    if p in (ns1.rowID, ns2.dscrpt, ns2.infl_outfl):
        filtered.add((s, p, o))

# „Éï„Ç£„É´„Çø„É™„É≥„Ç∞ÁµêÊûú„Çí„Éï„Ç°„Ç§„É´„Å´‰øùÂ≠ò
filtered.serialize(destination="rows_filtered_100.ttl", format="turtle")

 

Step 2ÔºöHANA Cloud„ÅÆTriple Store„Å´„Éá„Éº„Çø„ÇíÊ†ºÁ¥ç

Ê¨°„Å´„ÄÅÁí∞Â¢ÉÂ§âÊï∞„Åã„ÇâË™çË®ºÊÉÖÂ†±„ÇíË™≠„ÅøËæº„Åø„ÄÅSAP HANA Cloud„Å´Êé•Á∂ö„Åó„Å¶RDF„Éá„Éº„Çø„ÇíTriple Store„Å∏Ê†ºÁ¥ç„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

import os
from hdbcli import dbapi
from dotenv import load_dotenv

load_dotenv(override=True)

def get_hana_connection():
    conn = dbapi.connect(
        address=os.getenv("HANA_ADDRESS"),
        port=int(os.getenv("HANA_PORT")),
        user=os.getenv("HANA_USER"),
        password=os.getenv("HANA_PASSWORD")
    )    
    print("Connected to HANA:", conn.isconnected())
    
    return conn

# HANA„Å®„ÅÆÊé•Á∂ö„ÇíÁ¢∫Á´ã
conn = get_hana_connection()
cursor = conn.cursor()

# RDF„Éï„Ç°„Ç§„É´„ÅÆË™≠„ÅøËæº„Åø
with open(rdf_filename, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as rdf_file:
    rdf_data = rdf_file.read()

# HANA„É≠„Éº„ÉâÁî®„ÅÆ„Éò„ÉÉ„ÉÄ„ÉºË®≠ÂÆö
graphname = 'financial_plan_statements_cashflow_filtered_100'
request_hdrs = (
    'rqx-load-protocol: true\r\n'
    f'rqx-load-filename: {rdf_filename}\r\n'
    f'rqx-load-graphname: {graphname}\r\n'
)

# SPARQL„ÇØ„Ç®„É™„ÅÆÂÆüË°å
cursor.callproc('SPARQL_EXECUTE', (rdf_data, request_hdrs, '', None))
conn.commit()

 

Step 3ÔºöSPARQL„Å´„Çà„Çã„Éá„Éº„ÇøÊ§úÁ¥¢

ÊúÄÂæå„Å´„ÄÅHANA Cloud „ÅÆ Triple Store „Å´Ê†ºÁ¥ç„Åï„Çå„Åü RDF „Éá„Éº„Çø„Çí„ÄÅSPARQL „ÇØ„Ç®„É™„ÇíÁî®„ÅÑ„Å¶Ê§úÁ¥¢„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ„Åì„Åì„Åß„ÅØ SPARQL_TABLE „Çí‰ΩøÁî®„Åó„ÄÅSQL Êñá„Åã„Çâ SPARQL „ÇØ„Ç®„É™„ÇíÂÆüË°å„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ„Åì„ÅÆÊñπÊ≥ï„Å´„Çà„Çä„ÄÅËø∞Ë™û„Åå dscrpÔºàË™¨ÊòéÔºâ„Åß„ÅÇ„Çã„Éà„É™„Éó„É´„ÅÆ„Åø„Çí„ÉÜ„Éº„Éñ„É´ÂΩ¢Âºè„ÅßÂèñÂæó„Åß„Åç„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

‰∏ÄÊñπ„Åß„ÄÅSPARQL_EXECUTE „ÇíÂà©Áî®„Åô„Çå„Å∞„ÄÅSPARQL „ÇØ„Ç®„É™„ÇíÁõ¥Êé•ÂÆüË°å„Åô„Çã„Åì„Å®„ÇÇÂèØËÉΩ„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ„Åü„Å†„Åó„ÄÅ„Åì„Å°„Çâ„ÅØ„É¨„Çπ„Éù„É≥„Çπ„Åå„ÉÜ„Ç≠„Çπ„ÉàÂΩ¢Âºè„ÅßËøî„Åï„Çå„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÄÅ„Éá„Éº„Çø„ÅÆÊõ∏„ÅçËæº„ÅøÂá¶ÁêÜ„Å´ÈÅ©„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

graphname = "financial_plan_statements_cashflow_filtered_100"

sparql = f"""
SELECT ?s ?p ?o
FROM <{graphname}>
WHERE {
  ?s ?p ?o .
  FILTER(STRSTARTS(STR(?p), "https://data.cityofnewyork.us/resource/_4ubz-8kkx/dscrpt"))
}
LIMIT 10
"""

sql = f"""
SELECT * 
FROM SPARQL_TABLE('{sparql}', 'rqx-query-language: sparql')
"""

cur = conn.cursor()
cur.execute(sql)
rows = cur.fetchall()
cur.close()

for row in rows:
    print(row)

‰∏äË®ò„ÇíÂÆüË°å„Åô„Çã„Å®„ÄÅ‰ª•‰∏ã„ÅÆÂá∫ÂäõÁµêÊûú„ÅåÂæó„Çâ„Çå„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

‰ª•‰∏ä„Åß„ÄÅHANA Cloud‰∏ä„ÅßRDF„Ç∞„É©„Éï„ÇíÊßãÁØâ„Åó„ÄÅPython„Åã„ÇâSPARQL„ÇØ„Ç®„É™„ÇíÁî®„ÅÑ„Å¶Êìç‰Ωú„Åô„ÇãÊñπÊ≥ï„Çí„ÅîÁ¥π‰ªã„Åó„Åæ„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ

„Åæ„Åü„ÄÅÊúÄËøë„Åß„ÅØËá™ÁÑ∂Ë®ÄË™û„ÇíSPARQL„ÇØ„Ç®„É™„Å´Â§âÊèõ„Åó„Å¶„Åè„Çå„Çã text2sparql „Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜÊäÄË°ì„ÇÇÊ≥®ÁõÆ„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ„Åì„Çå„Çí‰Ωø„Åà„Å∞„ÄÅ„ÄåÁå´„ÇíÈ£º„Å£„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã‰∫∫„ÇíÊïô„Åà„Å¶„Äç„ÅÆ„Çà„ÅÜ„Å™Ë≥™Âïè„ÇíÂÖ•Âäõ„Åô„Çã„Å†„Åë„Åß„ÄÅË£èÂÅ¥„ÅßSPARQL„ÅåÁîüÊàê„Åï„Çå„Å¶ÁµêÊûú„ÇíËøî„Åó„Å¶„Åè„Çå„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ‰ªäÂæå„ÅØ„ÄÅ„Åì„ÅÆ„Çà„ÅÜ„Å™ÁîüÊàêAIÊäÄË°ì„Å®ÁµÑ„ÅøÂêà„Çè„Åõ„Çã„Åì„Å®„Åß„ÄÅ„Åï„Çâ„Å´Áõ¥ÊÑüÁöÑ„Å´„Éä„É¨„ÉÉ„Ç∏„Ç∞„É©„Éï„ÇíÊ¥ªÁî®„Åô„Çã„Åì„Å®„ÅåÊúüÂæÖ„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

entry.title: Discrepancy in HANA DB Size Reporting Between Production System and SAP for Me
entry.content:
Dear Team,

We have observed a discrepancy in the reported HANA database size for our production system integrated with ALM.

  • In our production system, the HANA database is showing 100 GB consumed out of 200 GB in sap cloud alm.
  • However, in SAP for Me -> "Finance and Legal" ->"Consumption" it shows 183 GB consumed out of 200 GB for the same system.

We would like to understand the reason for this mismatch and request your assistance in resolving the issue or clarifying the reporting mechanism used in SAP for Me.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Discrepancy in HANA DB Size Reporting Between Product...
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

In SAP Cloud ALM Health Monitoring, it collects the used memory only, while in the metric CY263 in SAP for Me, it is counting for the allocated memory. 
Please refer to the following blog which provided a very detailed explanation to your question:

Understanding HANA memory related license utilization in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

=> 3-System Landscape ‚Äì (Metric ID CY263)

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.content:
How to set the e-mail address for the user who will send case to SAP and receive case notification from SAP?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: BYD2508 How to change the e-mail address which will r...
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

 

The notification of the case is sent to the contact person registered for the case, that is, the processor who sent the case to SAP. When sending a case to SAP from ByD, Business User is used, so the email is the Business User's email.

If the Business User is linked to an employee, you can go to Personnel Administration - Employee view, edit the employee profile, and maintain the email in the workplace contact data under the employment tab.

If the Business User is linked to a service agent, you can go to Business Partner - Service Agent view, edit the service agent, and maintain the email in the email field.

 

Best Regards,

Cariford

entry.title: Re: To display Case and service request
entry.content:
Hi Pratap,

To ensure that an S-user can access and manage all cases and service requests, the following authorizations are required:

2669783 - S-user authorizations required for the Private Cloud Service Request application - SAP for Me

  • Create Billable Service Requests    Note: If templates are missing, the authorization needs to be set at the customer number or CCOE level (not just installation number level) - see KBA 3463116.
  • Create Service Requests
  • Display Service Requests
  • Report Technical Problem is also needed in order to create or display service requests

3383142 - Which S-user ID authorizations are required for support case handling? - SAP for Me

The required authorizations are as follows:

  • Report Technical Problem
  • Close Cases (see KBA 2646108)
  • Send Cases to SAP (see KBA 2656179)
  • Display Cases
  • Display all Cases
  • Display Cloud Data (applies to SAP Cloud products only, e.g. SuccessFactors, refer to KBA 2598170)

Administrators listed in the  Users & Contacts - SAP for Me can assign these authorizations to other S-users. For the "Display Cloud Data" authorization, users should contact a Cloud administrator listed in  My Important Contacts to request the necessary permissions, as outlined in KBA 1511008. 

For security purposes, I recommend reaching out to your company's administrators to ensure the required authorizations are assigned to the relevant S-users. If you need further assistance or clarification, please feel free to let me know.

Best regards,
Judy
SAP Support

entry.title: Check Payment 101: A Comprehensive Guide on Check Payment in SAP S4/HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
This blog post aims to serve as a comprehensive guide to help you understand the fundamentals of check payments in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. We will cover everything from creating check payments to tracking the check processing and managing check output, and briefly touch on positive pay. Read on to delve into the details!

Understanding Check Payments

What is Check Payment

A check payment is a traditional form of payment where a payer instructs their bank to pay a specific amount to the payee. The check contains essential details such as the payer's account number, the payee's name, the amount to be paid, and the payer's signature.

Key Information in a check payment

  • Bank Details: Includes the payer's bank account and routing numbers.
  • Payee Details: Name of the recipient.
  • Amount: The specific sum to be paid.
  • Date: The date the check is issued.
  • Signature: Authorization from the payer.
  • Check Number: Unique identifier for the check.

Creating and Managing Check Payments 

How to create a check payment

  • Bank Prints the Check on Behalf of the Payer

Here, the payer's bank is responsible for printing and issuing the check. The payer sends the check files to the bank, and the bank prints the check out and sends to the payee.

  • Payer Prints the Check

In this scenario, the payer purchases check books from the bank, and prints the check using their own printing facilities and then issue the checks to the payee.  This scenario is more commonly used by enterprises.

The following steps are required in this case:

1. Create payment medium format for checks in the Create Payment Medium Format configuration activity.

Define the format output type, specify a code page for download, add format parameters and supplements, and define payment medium granularity.

2. Define the rules for mapping data to the payment medium format files in the Map Format Data for Payments app (ID: F2685A).

Create a DMEE format tree, define the format mapping, and assign the mapping to the payment medium format.

3. Assign the payment medium format to a payment method in the Set Up Payment Methods for Each Country/Region for Payment Transactions configuration activity.

4. Assign the payment method to a checkbook in the Manage Checkbooks app (ID: F1577).

Create a checkbook, define the number range of the checkbook, and assign the payment method to the checkbook.

5. Create a variant for the payment medium format and define the parameters using the Create/Assign Selection Variants (Alternative) configuration activity.

After completing these steps, the payment medium format is ready for use when generating payment medium files for check payments, which will be sent to the bank. For detailed procedures, see Configuring Payment Medium Formats. After receiving the check payment files, the bank will then print out the checks and send them to the payee.

Configuring the Output for Checks

To ensure checks are printed correctly, the payer needs to configure the check format and output parameter determination in the business system. This involves defining the layout and printing parameters.

  • Standard Output with Check Form Templates

The standard way to configure output for checks is to do it in the Business Rule Framework (BRF+).  The form template FIN_FO_PAYM_CHECK_US is delivered by SAP for outgoing checks. You can use it to print checks when you configure the output of the outgoing checks. You can also configure your own form template to be used for outgoing checks based on this template. It is important that you need to ensure the form template you want to use for check output has been maintained in the Set Up Payment Methods per Company Code for Payment Transactions configuration activity. The detailed procedure has been described in the documentation. See Configuring the Output of Outgoing Checks on the SAP Help Portal.

  • Check Layout with MICR

MICR (Magnetic Ink Character Recognition) codes are crucial for automated check processing. It is a character recognition system using special ink and characters that can be magnetized and read automatically. MICR is used almost exclusively in the banking industry where it is used to print details on checks to enable automatic processing. Learn how to customize the check layout to include MICR lines by following this blog post.

  • Check Layout with Remittance

For checks that include remittance information,  display of additional details such as the invoice number, remittance date, and payment amount can be achieved by configuring the form layout. Choose to list the invoices paid in a payment run either in a payment advice or directly on the check form. Note that if the invoices are listed in a payment advice, they will not be listed on the check form.

In the configuration activity Set Up Payment Methods per Company Code for Payment Transactions (101044), define these settings in the Payment Advice Note Control section. The basic principle is to determine whether to list the invoices on the check form or in a payment advice based on the number of invoices. 

If Note to payee line on the form = None, and Payment advice output according to no. of lines = Always Payt. Adv, you're specifying that the invoice details should always be displayed in a payment advice.

After an automatic payment run, when displaying the check document in the Manage Outgoing Checks app, the remittance details will not appear on the check, but they will be presented in the payment advice form.

Similarly, you can specify a limit for the number of invoices to be displayed on the check form. If the number of invoices in a payment is beyond this max number, the remittance information will be displayed in a payment advice form instead. For example, if the payment is created for 2 invoices and the item text not considered (the number of invoice and invoice item text are summed to be compared to max number), the number of invoices is still within the limit.

On the check document, the remittance information for both invoices will available, given that the limit has not been exceeded.

Instead, if item text are not excluded: 

In a payment created for 2 invoices with two item texts, the number of invoice plus the item text for the invoices is larger than the limit 2, the invoice details will be displayed in a payment advice form, and will not be available on the check form.

For more information about how to pop up remittance information on a check form, see the SAP Knowledge Base Article: 2801192 - Check rules for populating Check Remittance or payment advice - SAP for Me.

Managing Checkbooks and Outgoing Check Payments

The following are some frequently used apps to manage checkbooks and outgoing check payments:

Manage Checkbooks (app ID: F1577).

This app can be used to:

  • Monitor usage and depletion status of existing checkbooks
  • Create new checkbooks
  • Reorder checkbooks and define successors to checkbooks in use
  • Void unused checks
  • Delete unused checkbooks
  • Edit checkbooks
  • Split checkbooks

Manage Outgoing Checks (app ID: F1578).

This app can be used to create/edit/void/cash/reissue outgoing checks. 

To create outgoing check payments, one frequently used app is Manage Automatic Payments (ID: F0770). After automatic payment runs with Check (C) as the payment method, the related check information is available in the payment output. In the processed check payments, the related checks are linked. Clicking the links will navigate to the Manage Outgoing Checks app to manage the checks. For detailed information, see Outgoing Checks on the SAP Help Portal.

Managing Positive Pay 

What is Positive Pay

Positive Pay is a fraud prevention service where the payer submits a list of check details (for example, serial number, amount) to the bank. The bank then verifies each check presented for payment against this list. The payer is alerted to any mismatches before the bank issues funds. The key difference between a positive pay file and a payment file is that the positive pay file is purely for verification, not for initiating payment. The following graphic depicts the positive pay process:

 Creating and Sending Positive Pay Files

There are multiple methods to generate and send positive pay files in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

  • Create Positive Pay Files (app ID: FCHX): The app can be used to manually create a file of check information that belongs to a paying company code. 
  • Job Template: Use the Creation of Positive Pay Files job template in the Schedule Accounts Payable Jobs app (ID: F2257) to automate the process using job templates.

After automatic generation of positive pay files using the job templates, the files can be sent to banks via API or Multi-Bank Connectivity (MBC), supported by the communication scenario SAP_COM_0251.

  • API: Use the API Positive Pay File - Send  to send positive files to the bank.
  • MBC: Integration with the SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity is required. To find out how to set up the MBC channel to send payment messages to the bank, see SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity .

 

Custom Positive Pay Formats Based on Bank Requirements

The payment medium format US_POSIPAY for positive pay files is pre-delivered. To support the payers to meet additional requirements from banks, copying the existing format and modifying it according to the bank's specifications is supported. Find more about configuration information in Create Positive Pay Files .

Summary

The above guide covers various aspects of check payments, from maintaining the output format to creating a check payment and then sending the payment files to the bank. Positive pay, as an additional option for preventing fraud in check payments, has also been introduced. Hopefully, you now have an overview of check payment. You can click the links to the specific topics about check payments in the SAP Help Portal. If you have any questions or anything you want to share, feel free to leave your comments and questions below.
