entry.title: Onboarding: Solutions to validate all required workPermit
entry.content:
Hello team, how are you?

As an Onboarding consultant, customers frequently request improvement regarding to validate all required workpermit on Hire/Rehire process.

Desire:
Don‚Äôt allow New Hires to complete Personal Data Collection if required workpermit are missing (i.e. as per Job, Country, Location).

Situation:
We know that business rules (onInit or onSave) can‚Äôt validate property all entries in workpermit, for example:

  • onInit rule: mostly on Rehire process, the rule only considers the first workpermit entry
  • onSave rule: the rule is processed for each workpermit entry

You might to recommend the newly step "Final Review". Yes, this can avoid New Hires to sign and complete their Process without required documentation, but what if we can avoid and block these looping? Of course, it will be better and will provide a seamless process. And this it‚Äôs the goal!

My question is, how you consultants are leading and providing solutions for this scenario to your customers?

Thank you!

@Gopinath_Murugaiyan

entry.title: Re: Re-initialization of a Table in a Replication Flow
entry.content:
Hi Tom, 

no, you do not need to remove from replication flow. Replication flows is the PI part of DSP. Just pause, add the field and resume. You do not affect other (max 499) replications with one (you can have up to 500 in one replication flow). 

Init -> will do full load automatically 

Init and delta -> will do full load (new field added) and then continue with delta

delta only -> will add the new field (you will not see the 'past', field will not be populated). 

More details here:

entry.title: Re: Cannot change directly folder for media with associat...
entry.content:
Dear phoude,

If you attempt to change the media folder directly when a media object already has associated data, the system can lose track of the object's actual location. If this is the case, the following consequences can occur:

  • The original data becomes abandoned, remaining in the media storage but no longer accessible to the system

  • The abandoned data is not removed or modified by deleting or updating a corresponding media entry, wasting storage space and preventing proper cleanup

To avoid these issues, the project.properties file includes a dedicated configuration property: media.folder.directFolderChangeGuard.enabled, set to true

With this default setting in place, whenever an action is performed on a media object, a related interceptor (PreventDirectFolderChangeForNonEmptyMediaValidateInterceptor) is activated

Caution

If you need to disable this protection, you can set media.folder.directFolderChangeGuard.enabled to false. However, this action is strongly discouraged as it risks the issues described above

The global guard is supplemented by a second line of defense: the session attribute allowDirectMediaFolderChange. You can use this attribute to temporarily bypass the guard for specific operations, allowing direct folder changes for media. The default setting is false. Changing the value to true explicitly allows direct folder changes, but only for the current session.

The system throws an InterceptorException, preventing the direct folder change, when the checks confirm that all the following conditions are met:
  • The media.folder.directFolderChangeGuard.enabled is true (default)
  • The allowDirectMediaFolderChange is false (default)
  • The MediaFolder reference has changed
  • The existing media has associated data
Note

The validation logic doesn't impose any restrictions on the creation of new media items. It's only applied when an existing media item with associated data is being moved to a different folder, and the direct folder change is not specifically allowed for the session

Also refer to this KBA 3607303 - Cannot change directly folder for media with associated data

entry.title: A Case Study: Mastering a Complex Rollout at a Utilities Enterprise
entry.content:
A utility company embarked on a transformative project focusing on process harmonization, establishing an ERP core as its backbone, and leveraging a merger with another enterprise to standardize processes while transitioning to S/4HANA. The rollout spanned a six-year roadmap involving more than 400 companies, 10+ countries, and over 30,000 SAP users.

The project‚Äôs complexity demanded significant attention and dedication. By its conclusion, the global team included around 10 workstreams, 25+ teams, and over 250 employees. What were the key success factors that enabled such an extensive and successful engagement?

Effective Planning

Thorough planning and preparation are fundamental to ensuring seamless cooperation and a successful go-live. In this case, the utilities company‚Äôs rollout adopted a targeted approach with clear goals. The initial rollouts for two pilot companies served as test runs to refine subsequent rollouts based on initial lessons learned.

In order to establish a Fit-to-Standard approach, a binding S/4HANA template was established, which was as closely aligned with SAP standards as possible, given the financial framework based on the analysis of the legal gaps. The template was built with the experts from all units to cover all requirements, which were later rolled out as the standard. Any exceptional requirements to enhance the template required a clear economic rationale, and local units had to justify the added value in case there were additional requirements. Remaining close to the SAP standard minimized the need for time-consuming custom developments, ensuring a rapid and efficient rollout. This approach minimized risks, controlled scope expansion, and reduced operational costs. The pilots tested the core template and helped derive valuable experience for a broader implementation.

Furthermore, the utilities company opted for a factory approach during the rollout of the project. Each factory had its tasks and responsibilities. The Test Factory, for example, ensured that E2E processes were tested and compliant with auditing standards and automation tools. The Migration Factory focused on data migrations with a specific standardized approach and tools to scale the migrations. The Cutover Factory ensured a successful and efficient go-live by leveraging cutover and steering tools, such as cutover plans and blueprints. The Communication and Change Factory‚Äôs task was to ensure the readiness of the people by informing, activating, and enabling all users with the respective knowledge transfer.

The utilities company‚Äôs ‚Äúfactory approach‚Äù balanced centralized governance with local execution. Central teams managed core activities like design, testing, and migration through specialized units, ensuring consistency and quality. Meanwhile, local teams addressed region-specific needs. This model fostered collaboration between central and local efforts, streamlining delivery and aligning global standards with local requirements. It enabled scalable, efficient rollouts by establishing a lean, standardized process and tool usage and ensuring transparency of all rollout steps.

Program Methodology and Governance

The customer opted for the SAP Activate methodology utilizing SAP Solution Manager (hereafter called SolMan) / Focus Build to ensure maximum transparency and run the project in an agile mode, enabling engagement of internal resources and time-efficient delivery despite COVID-19 remote work restrictions.

In the design and realization phase, the program scope was broken into three main waves, which were delivered by scrum teams, resulting in various agile sprint teams. SAP SolMan was the single source of truth, providing transparency and using scrum boards to ensure that all topics were tracked. The project also had clear guidelines and quality criteria, such as criteria for test completion and resulting documentation. The overall agile methodology, as well as SAP SolMan, resulted in the timely delivery of qualitative results by being responsive to changing requirements.

Strong program governance was another crucial factor. Initiatives of varying sizes and scopes benefit from centralized management and logical team clusters. Efficient project management methodologies and program leadership can significantly impact outcomes.

The utilities company‚Äôs governance structure included a lean finance stream supported by parallel integration and technology streams. Agile scrum teams managed deliverables dynamically, with 20 such teams driving the project forward. Over 90% of the scope was implemented within SAP standards due to robust and strict governance.

Strong governance also facilitated risk mitigation. Centrally organized meetings provided visibility to address key challenges promptly, such as restaffing roles when necessary. The utilities company and SAP collaboratively tackled issues, ensuring success through cross-team performance and motivated staff.

Structured Rollout Phases: The Core Fit2Standard Timeline

A critical enabler of the successful rollout was the structured sequencing of rollout phases within the Core Fit2Standard framework.

The utilities company adopted a phased approach that guided each rollout unit through clear steps of preparation, analysis, validation, and approval, ensuring alignment across all entities.

The process began with Local Units‚Äô Preparation, where onboarding, the collection of local information, and team setup established the foundation. This was followed by System Demos, introducing system landscape concepts and demonstrating template processes to ensure familiarity and clarity. The Local System Analysis phase identified requirements and gaps, including necessary local adjustments. These findings then moved into Template Validation, where potential gaps were discussed, categorized, and prioritized transparently.

After validation, the Review and Approval stage involved product owners and management making final decisions on gaps and their solutions, creating an efficient and constructive core Fit2Standard process. Finally, the Upload and Planning phase ensured that requirements were transferred to the backlog, dependencies were assessed, and handovers to the template team were executed smoothly.

Key success factors for this structured rollout included proactive participation in info sessions, thorough self-studies, and the use of InfoCollectors for pre-filled data gathering. Alignment between central and local units was emphasized, with local teams responsible for ensuring that regional requirements (e.g., legal obligations) were adequately addressed. Open discussion of potential gaps, along with clear prioritization, built trust and enabled efficient resolution. This structured phasing fostered transparency, minimized surprises, and kept the program aligned with the overall project roadmap.

Collaboration and Empowerment

Collaboration across teams and the entire project ecosystem is vital for smooth implementation. Effective change management‚Äîencompassing stakeholder management, awareness building, and resistance mitigation‚Äîcreates confidence and unity among affected teams.

The utilities company prioritized collaboration by adopting the philosophy ‚Äúfrom us for us,‚Äù engaging business, IT, central, regional teams, and partners. High levels of internal resource commitment ensured everyone actively contributed to the rollout. This large-scale engagement resulted in seamless cooperation among all parties involved.

One key lesson learned was the importance of separating program steering from content steering. Trusting system and topic owners to act in the company‚Äôs best interest proved invaluable. Addressing challenges directly as they arose ensured smooth progress. Additionally, a clear escalation procedure minimized hurdles and effort, contributing to the project‚Äôs success.

Furthermore, a key element of the project was the decision and escalation path, which vested more than 80% of the decisions by the product owners. These individuals took ownership and made decisions once unresolved topics were escalated to them. Product Managers were granted the mandate to make decisions related to cross-team matters. In this way, the product owners were empowered to take decisions and remained engaged, sharing a vested interest in the project‚Äôs success.

Driving Success in Rollout Management

The utilities company‚Äôs rollout exemplifies the principles of successful SAP implementations, especially for complex solutions like S/4HANA. Key factors included:

Effective Planning: Careful preparation, piloting, and the establishment of a binding Fit-to-Standard template ensured clarity of scope and minimized unnecessary custom developments.

Program Methodology and Governance: A robust governance framework, supported by the SAP Activate methodology and SAP Solution Manager, delivered alignment, transparency, and adaptability through agile execution and strong risk management.

Structured Rollout Phases: A transparent, phased Core Fit2Standard timeline guided each rollout unit from preparation through to planning, ensuring alignment across all entities and fostering consistent execution.

Collaboration and Empowerment: Unified teams with clearly defined responsibilities, empowered product owners, and a collaborative ‚Äúfrom us for us‚Äù philosophy fostered stakeholder engagement, accelerated decision-making, and ensured project ownership.

This case study demonstrates how disciplined planning, structured rollout phases, strong governance, and a collaborative culture can transform daunting challenges into scalable successes. For organizations embarking on similar transformative journeys, these strategies are not just recommended‚Äîthey are essential.

The lessons learned extend beyond technology. They highlight the importance of structure, discipline, and unity in navigating complex rollouts. By adopting these principles, organizations can achieve their goals while maintaining operational excellence and driving meaningful change.

 

********
Co-Author: Oliver-Jens G√∂tz

entry.title: Streamlining Data with SAP CPI Message Mapping : Sorting and Eliminating Incomplete Records
entry.content:
Introduction

In enterprise integration scenarios, managing employee data across systems is a common requirement ‚Äî but raw data is often messy or incomplete.

In this blog, we‚Äôll walk through a real-world solution in SAP Integration Suite (CPI) where we:
‚Ä¢ Filter out invalid employee records using Message Mapping
‚Ä¢ Sort valid employee records by EmployeeID using Groovy Script
‚Ä¢ Deliver a clean and structured employee dataset to the target system

The goal is to streamline incoming employee data so it‚Äôs ready for consumption by downstream applications.

Business Requirement
We needed to:
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ Remove employees missing EmployeeID
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ Preserve only complete records with all required fields
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ Sort the remaining employee records in ascending order by EmployeeID

This reflects a common need in systems like SAP SuccessFactors, SAP HCM, or third-party HR tools where employee records must be clean and ordered.

Note: 
The entire filtering and sorting of employee data could be handled using just a Groovy script. However, here I chose to use Message Mapping for filtering and Groovy only for sorting.
This approach helps demonstrate how standard tools in SAP CPI can be combined effectively ‚Äî and it‚Äôs especially helpful for beginners learning both graphical and scripting options.

‚öôÔ∏èTools Used
‚Ä¢ SAP Integration Suite (CPI)
‚Ä¢ Message Mapping ‚Äì to filter out incomplete data
‚Ä¢ Groovy Script ‚Äì to sort valid data
‚Ä¢ No external tools, APIs, or adapters needed

Better Picture

                              Sample input                                                                                    Desired Output
           


Steps to follow

  • Step 1: Filter Incomplete Records Using Message Mapping. In CPI, we first create a Message Mapping between the source and target structures (Employees ‚Üí Employees).
    Goal: remove any <Employee> node where EmployeeID is missing or empty.

    Functions Used:
    ‚Ä¢ removeContext : Flattens or isolates repeated elements from their surrounding hierarchy, treating each entry as a separate context so that they can be processed individually
    ‚Ä¢ Length: return the number of characters in the given string (used here to check if EmployeeID is empty or not).
    ‚Ä¢ GreaterThan: compares two numbers and returns true if the first is greater than the second.
    ‚Ä¢ constant: provides a fixed value to compare against.
    ‚Ä¢ createIf: creates the corresponding target node only if the connected Boolean condition is true.



    EmployeeID(on source side) is mapped to Employee(on target side) to only pass records having non-empty EmployeeID.
    This is known as conditional node creation.
    Below is the mapping expression used to conditionally create nodes having non-empty EmployeeID.



    We map the rest of the fields directly one to one like shown below.




  • Step 2: Sort Valid Records Using Groovy Script

    Important Tip: Why We Use Groovy for Sorting
    üö´Message Mapping in SAP CPI cannot perform sorting operations.
    ‚úÖIt is designed for mapping and filtering data, but not for ordering or rearranging nodes.

    That‚Äôs why sorting must be handled by a Groovy script (or other scripting steps like XSLT) if required.
    If your source system can sort data (e.g., an OData service or database), it‚Äôs best to sort at the source when possible.
    But when that‚Äôs not feasible, a post-mapping script like the one we used is the recommended approach.

    Below is the groovy script used in this.



    iFlow Design
    The iFlow created looks something like this.


    Final Thoughts

    With just two steps we‚Äôve transformed raw employee data into a clean, filtered, and sorted dataset ready for use.

    This approach can be applied to:
    ‚Ä¢ HR integrations
    ‚Ä¢ Payroll systems
    ‚Ä¢ Internal reporting systems
    ‚Ä¢ Master data consolidation flows

entry.title: Monitor CAPM service crashes using SAP BTP Alert Notification Service
entry.content:
SAP Alert Notification Service is a powerful service available on the Business Technology Platform (BTP) that helps you to monitors your applications and sends alerts when something goes wrong like an application crash so you can take immediate action.

Few things to which are required to setup beforehand:

  1. A subaccount in SAP BTP.
  2. A space created within that subaccount.
  3. Required services (capm) deployed in that space to enable monitoring.
  4. To use the Alert Notification Service, it must be subscribed within your BTP subaccount.

Now Let's create and configure Alert Notification Service

Once Create, Make sure this configuration is enabled already within the instance parameters

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


There are few terms which is very important and are explained below:

  • Events: These are the triggers specific occurrences like application crashes that the system watches for.
  • Actions: These define what should happen when a particular event is detected
  • Subscription: This is the link between events and actions. It listens for selected events and executes the configured actions when those events occur.
Flow within the Alert Notification Service:

Subscription will act as your entry point. It listens to all incoming events but only responds to the ones it‚Äôs configured for. Once a matching event is detected, it triggers the corresponding action

Configuring the Alert Notification Service:

Open the ANS dashboard, follow these steps to begin monitoring application crashes:

  1. Navigate to the "Conditions" menu.
  2. Create a new condition and set the Event Type to: app.crash
  3. This condition will help ANS identify and respond to application crash events.
Now That the Condition Is Set, Let‚Äôs Create an Action

Next, head over to the ‚ÄúActions‚Äù menu from the left-hand panel in the Alert Notification Service dashboard. This is where you‚Äôll define what should happen when your configured event like app.crash is triggered.

Select Action Type as Email and click on next

In the Actions menu, start by entering a name for your action. Then, specify the email address where you want to receive alert notifications and click on Create button

Note:  After adding your email address to the action, you‚Äôll receive a confirmation email. Make sure to verify it before moving forward - this step is essential to start receiving alert notifications.

Now That the Action Is Set, Let‚Äôs Create a Subscription

Next, head over to the ‚ÄúSubscriptions‚Äù menu from the left-hand panel in the Alert Notification Service dashboard. 
Give some meaningful name and description and select your newly created action and condition as shown below:

 

 


 




 

 

 

 

 

 

Note: You might see a section called store-events in the dashboard. This was created for a different purpose, so feel free to ignore it during your setup - it‚Äôs not relevant to the current configuration.

Click Save, and just like that you‚Äôve successfully created a subscription! Your Alert Notification Service is now ready to listen for events and take action as configured.

From now on, whenever a service crashes within the same space where your Alert Notification Service instance is set up, you‚Äôll receive an email notification, just like the one shown below. 

 


Conclusion
Using SAP Alert Notification Service, we can now monitor services in real time. If any service crashes, we‚Äôll receive instant alerts containing detailed information about the event.
